qas.question: What is emitted as a result of the photoelectric effect?
What does the kinetic energy of a photoelectron depend on?
What happens if the photoelectron's frequency is too low?

answers.text: no photoelectrons are emitted at all

qas.question: What is the term used when photoelectrons act virtually at the same time?
What type of energy due photoelectrons emitted due to the photoelectric effect have?
What factor of the initial light source does the energy of the photoelectrons depend on?
When the photon energy is less than the work function of the material the light is shone upon, how many photoelectrons are emitted?

answers.text: no photoelectrons are emitted at all

qas.question: If the photoelectric effect is occuring, increasing the intensity of the light source causes what?

answers.text: more photoelectrons to be emitted with the same kinetic energy

qas.question: What is infused as a result of the photoneutral effect?
What does the kinetic energy of a photoelectron lose?

plausible_answers.text: no photoelectrons are emitted at all

qas.question: What happens if the photoelectron's frequency stays the same?
What type of energy due photoelectrons emitted due to the photoneutral effect have?

context: The "<a0_0><b8_0>photoelectrons<b8_0/><a0_0/>" emitted as a result of the photoelectric effect have a certain <a4_0>kinetic<a4_0/> energy, which can be measured. This kinetic energy (for each photoelectron) is independent of the intensity of the light, but depends linearly on <a1_0><b9_0>the <a5_0>frequency<b9_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/>; and if the frequency is too low (corresponding to a photon energy that is less than the work function of the material), <a2_0><a6_0><b10_0>no photoelectrons are emitted at all<b10_0/><a6_0/><a2_0/>, unless a plurality of photons, whose energetic sum is greater than the energy of the photoelectrons, acts virtually simultaneously (<a3_0>multiphoton effect<a3_0/>)  Assuming the frequency is high enough to cause the photoelectric effect, a rise in intensity of the light source causes <a7_0>more photoelectrons to be emitted with the same kinetic energy<a7_0/>, rather than the same number of photoelectrons to be emitted with higher <b11_0>kinetic<b11_0/> energy.
